description: The Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) is a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for finding the ground state energy of a molecular Hamiltonian. It uses a parameterized quantum circuit (ansatz) to prepare trial wavefunctions, measures the energy expectation value, and classically optimizes the parameters.
VQE is one of the most promising near-term applications of quantum computing for quantum chemistry, with potential applications in drug discovery, materials science, and catalysis.
Chemical accuracy (errors < 1.6 mHa or ~1 kcal/mol) is required for practically useful predictions. Achieving this on NISQ devices requires sophisticated error mitigation strategies.
why_qem: VQE circuits for chemically interesting molecules require significant depth, making them susceptible to noise. Even small errors in energy estimates can lead to qualitatively wrong predictions about molecular properties.

Symmetry verification is particularly powerful for VQE because molecular Hamiltonians conserve particle number, spin, and spatial symmetries. Measurements violating these symmetries can be discarded or corrected.
N-representability constraints from quantum chemistry provide additional physical constraints that can be used to project noisy reduced density matrices onto the physically allowed manifold.
Zero-noise extrapolation and Clifford data regression leverage the structure of VQE circuits to learn and correct systematic errors.

demonstrations.title: H₂ and LiH on Superconducting Hardware
demonstrations.description: Early demonstrations of VQE with error mitigation achieved chemical accuracy for small molecules using measurement error mitigation and symmetry verification.

demonstrations.title: BeH₂ with ZNE
demonstrations.description: Extended VQE to larger molecules using zero-noise extrapolation to correct gate errors, demonstrating the scalability of error-mitigated quantum chemistry.

demonstrations.title: H₂ Ground State with Quantum Error Detection (2020)
demonstrations.description: Demonstrated that encoding qubits in the [[4,2,2]] error-detecting code improves accuracy of chemical calculations on quantum computers. The QED approach achieved better results than unencoded circuits for estimating the hydrogen molecule ground state energy.

challenges: Barren plateaus in variational optimization can be exacerbated by noise
Symmetry verification acceptance rates decrease with circuit depth
Classical simulation of training circuits for CDR becomes expensive for large molecules
Hardware-efficient ansatze may not preserve chemical symmetries, limiting symmetry verification
